1.text:
PARASILITI: Welcome to today's Council on
Foreign Relations meeting on the Syrian refugee

5.text:
crisis. I am Andrew Parasiliti. I'm director
of the Center for Global Risk and Security

11.text:
at the RAND Corporation.
In addition to a death toll now numbering

16.text:
190,000, the U.N. High Commission on Refugees
has documented 3 million Syrian refugees outside

23.text:
Syria and another 6.5 million displaced within
the country. The highest concentration of

31.text:
refugees outside Syria are in Lebanon, 1.2
million out of a population of approximately

36.text:
4.4 million, 616,000 in Jordan, 213,000 in
Iraq, 140,000 in Egypt, and now approaching

45.text:
1 million in Turkey, given the exodus following
the activity and warfare around Kobani.

53.text:
Half of the refugees are women and girls,
and at least 25 percent are children seventeen

58.text:
or younger. To compare, there are approximately
3 million Palestinian refugees in Lebanon,

64.text:
Jordan and Syria. The U.S. has provided $2.9
billion in humanitarian aid to Syria, with

71.text:
$1.4 billion to help address the refugee crisis.
As long as the war continues, I think we can

76.text:
expect that the refugee crisis, which is already
urgent, will go from bad to worse. And absent

83.text:
a political solution in Syria, which includes
addressing the refugee crisis, they could

89.text:
become, these refugees, a regular feature
of Middle East politics, furthering political

94.text:
and economic strain on Jordan and Lebanon
in particular, in addition to the urgent humanitarian

99.text:
assistance required to assist these populations.
To discuss the refugee crisis, I'm pleased

105.text:
to welcome Jeffrey Crisp, senior director
for policy and advocacy at Refugees International;

111.text:
and Rochelle Davis, associate professor of
cultural anthropology at the Center for Contemporary

115.text:
Arab Studies at the Edmund A. Walsh School
of Foreign Service, Georgetown University.

120.text:
Both have extensive experience dealing with
refugees in Syria and the Middle East and

126.text:
elsewhere. And let me remind our speakers
and our audience that this meeting is on-the-record.

131.text:
Rochelle, let me start with you. Last year,
when I was with Al-Monitor, I interviewed

139.text:
Kristalina Georgieva, the former European
Union's commissioner for international cooperation,

145.text:
humanitarian aid, and crisis response. And
she told me that Syria, quote, "is the crisis

151.text:
that makes me lose my sleep," unquote. That
was last year.

155.text:
Please put the Syria refugee crisis in global
context for us. How bad is it? And can it

162.text:
get worse?
DAVIS: I think it can get worse, unfortunately.

165.text:
I think what we're looking at, if we take
Syria's total population of -- sorry, of 22

172.text:
million people and the numbers you cited total
almost 10 million people displaced from their

178.text:
homes, so half of the country is no longer
living in their places of residence or their

182.text:
homes, I mean, that should make people sort
of pause to think about.

188.text:
The other thing that I think we're seeing,
because this is -- we're into the -- sort

192.text:
of the third year of a large refugee movement
outside of the country and displacement inside

199.text:
of the country is that those people who are
finally crossing borders, whereas three years

206.text:
ago they may have crossed borders with some
money and they may have been fleeing sort

209.text:
of political oppression, now they're fleeing
with nothing. And they're coming even more

213.text:
destitute and after three years of really
difficult conditions inside Syria.

219.text:
So they don't come with either internal resilience
to sort of keep themselves together very much,

228.text:
although they are survivors, and they don't
come with material things to survive. And

232.text:
so I think we're going to see increasingly
more desperate movement of refugees, depending

238.text:
on where it's happening.
PARASILITI: Peter, compared to a year ago,

242.text:
we now have the situation in Iraq, since June,
with the Islamic State coming there. How has

248.text:
-- how has the situation in Iraq compounded
the Syrian refugee crisis?

252.text:
CRISP: Well, you've already outlined the severity
of the Syrian refugee crisis in terms of the

257.text:
numbers within the region, which is, of course,
enormous and which have taken place just in

261.text:
three year -- just over three years.
And I guess one could say that the last thing

265.text:
that the region needed was another large-scale
displacement, but as the result of the territorial

270.text:
gains made recently by ISIS, that is exactly
what has happened. There's been a massive

275.text:
outflow of people within and from Iraq.
I've not been to the region personally myself,

281.text:
but a couple of my colleagues are in the audience,
have been there recently, and so they've been

285.text:
able to provide me with some kind of firsthand
information about what's happening. So let

288.text:
me just briefly outline some of the consequences
of the -- of what's been happening in Iraq.

293.text:
Firstly, as I said, massive new displacements,
800,000 IDPs moving from lower Iraq to northern

301.text:
Iraq. And, of course, there are already 200,000
Syrian refugees in that area. Unfortunately,

307.text:
the Baghdad government has not been providing
the support which is required to enable the

311.text:
north of the country to support that many
newly displaced people. 140,000 new refugees

317.text:
to Turkey, which as you've said is already
housing well over 1 million Syrian refugees.

323.text:
The new influx from Iraq has also put increased
pressure on scarce humanitarian funds. I think

329.text:
as most of the audience will know, there's
been a spate of recent emergencies -- South

334.text:
Sudan, Central African Republic, Syria, et
cetera -- humanitarian budgets were already

338.text:
under severe pressure. The recent events in
Iraq have put even more pressure on that.

343.text:
And similarly, the capacity of the humanitarian
system to respond to this new crisis has been

349.text:
limited. I was in Geneva just last week, and
some of my former colleagues at UNHCR were

354.text:
describing how difficult it is to find experienced
humanitarian aid workers who are prepared

359.text:
to go to the field and stay there for substantial
period of time. So the humanitarian system

363.text:
is struggling.
And then just one other thing I would add

368.text:
is that I think one of the key problems that
we're going to be confronting in northern

372.text:
Iraq at the moment is the whole question of
winterization. The winter onset is coming

378.text:
quite soon, within two to three weeks, the
end of October. As you know, it gets extremely

382.text:
cold in the north of Iraq. The conventional
tents and other equipment provided to refugees

387.text:
in the summer are simply not adequate. So
there will be a need for a massive push, and

391.text:
that, of course, will require additional funding
to winterize the accommodation that the refugees

397.text:
have in northern Iraq.
PARASILITI: Thank you. You mentioned, Peter,

401.text:
about how Iraq was responding to the crisis.
Rochelle, if you could -- you could pick up

405.text:
on that, tell us, how are the countries of
the region coping with the refugee flow? Peter

411.text:
mentioned Iraq, but what's being done...
DAVIS: Jeff.

414.text:
PARASILITI: Sorry, Jeff, I'm sorry -- sorry,
Jeff.

416.text:
CRISP: That's OK.
PARASILITI: What's being done, what's not

418.text:
being done to handle the refugee flows in
Iraq, Jordan, Lebanon, and Turkey. Is there

425.text:
a capacity to do more? Or are they already
maxed out in terms of this capacity?

430.text:
DAVIS: I think it's really important, first
and foremost, to recognize the generosity

434.text:
of the host countries who have kept their
borders open for the most part and allowed

438.text:
in, I mean, many hundreds of thousands of
fleeing people in desperate situations. And

444.text:
so everyone can always do more, but I think
it's really important to recognize what they

450.text:
have -- what those countries have done.
And I think -- a useful way to look at it

456.text:
is to divide them into sort of two groups
with Turkey and Jordan being countries that

461.text:
have a very strong centralized government
that provides services to its population,

467.text:
health and education, and that are very intent
on kind of keeping -- keeping those systems

474.text:
functioning. And they -- particularly Jordan,
based on its experience with Iraqi refugees

480.text:
-- have tried to incorporate Syrian refugees
into those education and health care systems,

484.text:
rather than recreate new systems in which
to -- in which to have them -- have them only

492.text:
be refugee-focused, although there are those,
as well, within those countries, because of

496.text:
the need.
And then you have other countries like Lebanon

500.text:
and Iraq which have very weak central government
control over education and health care and

507.text:
security and some of those other things. And
that has been where humanitarian organizations

513.text:
and U.N. bodies have really stepped to the
fore and tried to provide these services,

519.text:
as well as local governorates and local municipalities
have also really had to kind of figure out

526.text:
how -- what to do with these people.
I mean, I think Lebanon is -- is -- is a country

532.text:
that we should sort of really be in awe of
because it has 4.47 million people in it,

539.text:
as you mentioned, with 1.2 million Syrians
in it, which is like 20 percent of its population

545.text:
has been added in the last three years.
And the fact that -- that there isn't wide-scale

551.text:
demonstrations among the Lebanese against
that -- I mean, there are certain flash points

556.text:
and touch points and violence, but the fact
that these countries and their populations

561.text:
have made it a point to live with the Syrians
and to try and make this work for everybody,

568.text:
as bumpy as it is, I think is a -- is important
to always remember.

573.text:
PARASILITI: Jeff, how do you evaluate what
-- we're hearing about what the Arab states

578.text:
are -- the neighbors are struggling with,
all of the neighbors, and the response from

584.text:
the United States, Europe, and the international
community? You said you were talking to contacts

588.text:
in Geneva and others who are addressing it.
What's being done? What more needs to be done?

594.text:
CRISP: I mean, given the recent spate of armed
conflicts and refugee movements and internally

599.text:
displaced situations, I think one has to acknowledge
that the international response has been quite

604.text:
impressive and quite substantive. You've already
given the figure of $3 billion from the U.S.

609.text:
government. My own country, the U.K., has
provided rather less, but still a significant

615.text:
amount of money, 700 million pounds.
And so I think one can say that the international

620.text:
response has been quite effective in terms
of the resources mobilized. An interesting

625.text:
characteristic of this crisis is the new money
coming in from what we call non-traditional

630.text:
donors, in other words, other states in the
Middle East, particularly in the Gulf. That

635.text:
kind of money is much harder to track. It
doesn't go through the conventional U.N. channels.

641.text:
And so it's been much more difficult to work
out exactly who's providing how much money

644.text:
and what it's going to, but it seems fairly
evident that there is a significant amount

649.text:
of new money coming in from the Arab states
and from individual donors in that region.

655.text:
PARASILITI: Is the money enough?
CRISP: Money is an essential starting point.

660.text:
I think the big question over any large-scale
humanitarian operation is, is that money being

667.text:
used in an effective and efficient manner?
I think almost inevitably -- and this is no

671.text:
excuse -- but almost inevitably, in any large-scale
humanitarian operation one can find examples

677.text:
of inefficiencies, wastage, perhaps even corruption.
I visited the region several times in the

684.text:
last couple of years. I haven't come across
large-scale evidence of that taking place.

689.text:
Something that I think is going to be very
interesting to watch is a very large-scale

692.text:
independent evaluation of the whole refugee
operation that UNHCR has just commissioned

698.text:
and will be publishing shortly. And I think
it would be extremely interesting to delve

702.text:
into that report to see what they find out
about the effectiveness and the efficiency.

707.text:
But certainly key donors -- not just the USA
and the U.K. -- are very eager to see that

712.text:
their dollars and their pounds are used in
the most effective way possible, have been

716.text:
monitoring the operation extremely closely,
and I've not heard any major complaints about

721.text:
the way that it's been run.
PARASILITI: And just one more question on

724.text:
the specifics of the aid. And you brought
up an interesting point about the winter coming.

729.text:
Is the first order of business--in dealing
with these flows of refugees--housing, health,

735.text:
education? How would you prioritize it? And
are we meeting all of them?

740.text:
CRISP: Yeah, I mean, I think unless you can
meet all of those key essential needs, people

743.text:
are going to be in trouble. Something I may
mention a little bit later on, I also -- with

748.text:
that in education. Education is often not
seen as a kind of lifesaving activity. It's

752.text:
seen sometimes as a bit of a luxury, and it's
the first thing to go when funding gets scarce.

757.text:
But I think if we're to think in terms of
the future of the Syrian population, the Syrian

762.text:
people, whether they remain in their countries
of asylum, whether they go back to Syria,

767.text:
whether they manage to move on to another
part of the world, having education and having

770.text:
skills is absolutely essential. So in addition
to kind of the essential needs that you've

775.text:
outlined, I would add education is an absolute
priority.

777.text:
PARASILITI: And it's a nice opening for me
to plug some of the work of the RAND Corporation

781.text:
in this area. Our Center for Middle East Public
Policy has been developing a project on tracking

788.text:
education, refugees, information in that regard,
and I think it's very important work.

793.text:
CRISP: If I could just add one -- one issue
that hasn't come up yet, which I think is

796.text:
worth mentioning, is something which is -- I
wouldn't say essentially unique, but it's

800.text:
unusual about this particular refugee situation,
is the fact that the vast majority of refugees

805.text:
are not housed in camps. In fact, according
to our calculations, probably 75 percent to

809.text:
80 percent of the 3.3 million refugees are
living with host communities, and that has

814.text:
some advantages. It's obviously more of a
natural lifestyle to live in a community,

818.text:
rather than living in a camp. And anybody
who's been to Zaatari Camp in Jordan can tell

823.text:
you this is not a natural environment for
people to live.

826.text:
But also, when people are scattered, it makes
it more difficult to access them, more difficult

830.text:
to identify the most vulnerable refugees,
and it actually may increase the potential

834.text:
for conflict or tension with the host communities,
because they're living side-by-side and sometimes

839.text:
competing for the same resources and the same
jobs.

842.text:
But I think it is quite an interesting aspect
of this crisis that has forced the humanitarian

848.text:
community to think much more systematically
about, what does it mean to provide relief

853.text:
to refugees who are not in camps?
PARASILITI: This is another nice opening.

857.text:
Rochelle, I know you've done work in the Palestinian
refugees over the years. If you could comment

864.text:
on what Jeffrey was mentioning, and how do
you see the impact of these refugee populations,

871.text:
Syrian refugees, Palestinian refugees, over
time, in terms of the political and economic

877.text:
challenges in the region, the governance challenges?
And are there lessons learned from the Palestinian

883.text:
refugee situation that we can apply here?
DAVIS: So I think there are lessons learned,

888.text:
particularly if we don't look at the international
community, but we look at the Arab countries

894.text:
that host Palestinians and the Palestinian
themselves. One of the things that I haven't

898.text:
heard talked about at all is how the Syrians
call themselves. And you'll notice they call

905.text:
themselves nazuhein (ph). They call themselves
displaced. They don't called themselves laj'een,

909.text:
which is refugees.
And following this up, I was told that because

914.text:
Palestinians are refugees, because they have
been displaced from their home since 1948

919.text:
and they haven't gone back, and the Syrians
say we're not those people, we're not going

923.text:
to be laj'een, we're not going to be like
the Palestinians. We're going back to Syria.

927.text:
And so everyone in these areas thinks of them
as people going back. Now, I think that may

933.text:
be shifting in some ways, as the conflict
really morphs into something that is not -- not

941.text:
sort of an opposition to Assad and Assad,
and people are caught in this and now may

947.text:
not want to go back, depending on what happens.
And it's hard to sort of draw other lessons

958.text:
from the Palestinian refugees in particular,
although it's important to note that almost

963.text:
-- sort of the vast majority -- there were
500 Palestinian refugees in Syria, most of

968.text:
whom still remain in Syria, because they've
-- Jordan closed its borders to them and will

972.text:
not let them in, and it's hard for them to
get into Lebanon. They have to have different

976.text:
sort of access, and they can enter, but they
end up being illegal very quickly. And they

981.text:
can't afford it, because Lebanon is very expensive
and they don't really have places to go anymore,

986.text:
because the Palestinian refugee camps in Lebanon
are so full, you can't even find an empty

992.text:
apartment in them.
But I think sort of most importantly, it's

1000.text:
actually the lesson of the Iraqi refugees
that many people draw on, because for Iraqis,

1008.text:
as well as for Syrians, as well as for Palestinian
refugees, they had to learn how to be refugees.

1014.text:
They had to learn how to think of themselves
as people who needed aid and to interact with

1020.text:
a community that was providing them aid in
a way that is not natural to any of us. We're

1025.text:
all sort of citizens of a state, and regardless
of the state's politics, we have a particular

1029.text:
relationship with that state.
And once you become a refugee, you have a

1033.text:
different relationship to the state authorities,
but you also have to think of yourselves differently.

1038.text:
And I did a series of interviews in Jordan
and Lebanon with Syrian refugees, and one

1043.text:
of the questions I thought was important to
ask, because no one -- in all the work I've

1048.text:
ever read on Palestinian refugees, had ever
asked it, and that was, what do you miss most

1053.text:
about your country or about your home or about,
you know, living in Syria?

1058.text:
And so we took all of their answers and compiled
them and published them in a piece called

1062.text:
"What Do You Miss Most?", because their answers
were so striking. And one man in particular

1069.text:
-- and it sort of resonated among -- out there
on the interwebs as it traveled, he said,

1074.text:
"I miss my dignity."
And I think that that's really sort of -- a

1079.text:
sort of important thing to remember about
how Syrians have had to learn to be displaced

1086.text:
like everyone else who's ever displaced, but
learn to be refugees, just as everyone else

1092.text:
has before them.
PARASILITI: What have we noticed in the refugee

1096.text:
camps in terms of political trends? I would
assume there's a lot of opposition politics,

1102.text:
activity, radical -- potential radicalization
of the populations. Or are they still just

1108.text:
focused on staying alive and trying to get
home?

1114.text:
DAVIS: In thinking about how to respond to
this question, I think it's really important

1119.text:
to always remember that people want to do
something to make their lives better. And

1125.text:
Syrians are the same way. And so for so many
Syrians, there aren't many options of what

1131.text:
to do. They've -- there are active movements
of nonviolent and civil sort of society movements

1142.text:
inside Syria that were very -- very resolutely
clamped down on by the Syrian government,

1152.text:
as well as internal Syrian opposition sort
of things going on. And now they are set with

1159.text:
the Islamic State. And so you have people
there who want to sort of make Syria come

1164.text:
back to life in whatever form that they believe
in. And they want to do something.

1171.text:
And so radicalization may be happening, but
it's because people, I think, in some ways

1178.text:
feel that there's something to do. And so,
I mean, I would advocate for there to be more

1184.text:
than just food and education and -- I mean,
I think education would be one of the most

1190.text:
important things to focus our attention on
now, but more than just sort of food and health

1194.text:
care, and thinking them as -- thinking of
Syrians as bodies to be cared for, but actually

1198.text:
to sort of cater more to their sort of mental
and spiritual selves, because they are resilient

1205.text:
and they will rebuild themselves and their
lives.

1207.text:
And so if there were projects out there for
them to do things, whether those are civil

1211.text:
society organizing among refugees, whether
that is, you know, training programs for them

1218.text:
to become, you know -- to have certain jobs,
I think that that would be a good step to

1223.text:
move away from radicalization and a move towards
sort of -- thinking of them as there's not

1233.text:
a lot of hope for them in the next couple
of years to go back or for them to be resettled.

1238.text:
CRISP: If I could just pick up on that, I
mean, it's a question I've been asked with

1242.text:
growing frequency over the past year, is the
experience of being an exile radicalizing

1247.text:
Syrian youth, particularly young men. And
I'm not totally surprised that that question

1251.text:
is being asked. It's an area that's characterized
by sectarian conflicts, but militant extremism,

1257.text:
religious extremism. So you put the two together
and it's easy to come up with (inaudible)

1262.text:
I would have to say that on my visits to the
region, talking to aid workers, talking to

1266.text:
national government officials, security officials,
I've never heard this issue raised as a major

1274.text:
concern. Now, in the longer term, just as
you've suggested, I think, you know, leaving

1278.text:
a population so large and coming from a country
where they had some education previously,

1285.text:
I think, leaving a country -- leaving this
population kind of festering without things

1289.text:
to do, there clearly is a risk of some form
of radicalization. I wouldn't go into the

1294.text:
details as to what form that might take.
So I think we really do as a humanitarian

1299.text:
community have to think through, what are
the kind of useful activities that we can

1303.text:
provide to these people? The obvious answer
to that is provide them with livelihoods.

1307.text:
And I think, you know, livelihoods would go
a long way to giving people a meaningful and,

1312.text:
as you mentioned, dignified existence.
The problem with that response is it's very

1317.text:
easy to say and much more difficult to implement.
You only have to go to a country like Egypt.

1322.text:
You go to Cairo. You can see mass unemployment
on the streets, young men, young women without

1327.text:
much to do. So the idea of suddenly creating
large numbers of jobs for Syrian refugees

1332.text:
becomes problematic: A, problematic in actually
creating the jobs and, B, creating jobs for

1338.text:
Syrians and not some potentially for Egyptians,
and thereby increasing the risk of tension

1342.text:
between the two.
So I think radicalization is a kind of an

1345.text:
issue that's worth thinking about, but we
have to think practically about what can be

1349.text:
done to give people the kind of dignified
life that would not lead them in that direction.

1355.text:
PARASILITI: Does the organized resettlement
of Syrian refugees in the U.S. and elsewhere

1361.text:
have a role to play in addressing the refugee
crisis?

1364.text:
CRISP: My answer to that question will be
very simple: yes and no. Let me explain why

1369.text:
I say yes and no. Yes, I think resettlement
to the USA and to other prosperous countries

1375.text:
-- and even less prosperous countries -- for
example, Uruguay recently set up a resettlement

1380.text:
program for Syrian refugees.
So I think the resettlement programs to the

1385.text:
U.S. and other prosperous countries would
send an important signal to the countries

1389.text:
in the region that they're not being left
alone, they're not being left to bear the

1393.text:
brunt of the reference influx by themselves,
that other states are willing to share the

1397.text:
responsibility and share the burden. And that
might encourage states in the region to keep

1402.text:
their borders open and to pursue decent policies
towards refugees.

1407.text:
The reason I will be also more cautious in
saying that resettlement offers any kind of

1411.text:
a solution is simply in terms of numbers.
In a situation where you've got 3.3 million

1417.text:
refugees at the moment, predicted to rise
to 3.59 by the end of the year by the United

1423.text:
Nations, if we take the U.S., which is the
world's leading resettlement country, it only

1427.text:
resettles 70,000 people per year. So even
if every one of those 70,000 slots were to

1434.text:
be given to a Syrian for the next three years
and taken out of the region, you'd still be

1439.text:
left with 3 million refugees in the region.
So I think in terms of numbers, we couldn't

1444.text:
really look to resettlement as a major part
of the solution. But in terms of a symbolic

1448.text:
gesture and maintaining solidarity with the
refugees in the region I think it has a small,

1454.text:
but valuable role to play.
PARASILITI: What are the specifics of a successful

1459.text:
resettlement program, just briefly?
CRISP: Well, the specifics of a successful

1464.text:
resettlement program will be firstly that
you identify the people who are most in need

1469.text:
of protection and the most vulnerable members
of the population. There's always been a tendency

1475.text:
on resettlement countries to say, let's grab
the best and the brightest and the best educated

1479.text:
people. But according to humanitarian principles,
resettlement should be really targeted at

1484.text:
the people with the most serious protection
problems and the most important vulnerabilities.

1489.text:
And then I think bringing things closer to
home, a successful resettlement program is

1493.text:
one that doesn't just bring people to a country,
dump them there, and leave them to get on

1498.text:
with their lives unsupported. You can imagine
bringing refugees from Syria or, indeed, any

1504.text:
other part of the world. Probably you don't
speak English, have not been educated in English,

1509.text:
bringing them to the U.S. and simply leaving
them by themselves would not be a great idea

1513.text:
in terms of their long-term future. So I think
adequate support in the country of resettlement

1517.text:
would be the second fundamental component
of successful resettlement.

1521.text:
DAVIS: Can I add something onto that?
PARASILITI: Yeah, please.

1523.text:
DAVIS: I've been thinking about this idea
about vulnerable and vulnerability in terms

1528.text:
of how we define refugees and look at them,
and those are traditionally people, women

1532.text:
and children, people with health issues and
the elderly. And I did a -- when I was doing

1537.text:
research, I was struck by how many young men
sort of between the ages of eighteen to thirty

1542.text:
were -- had fled Syria because they didn't
-- because they were going to be conscripted

1547.text:
into the Syrian army and didn't want to fight
in the army against other Syrians and kill

1552.text:
other Syrians. And so they fled the country.
And they have a lot of problems in the host

1559.text:
countries, because they don't often come with
their families. Their families often send

1562.text:
them out or fake their kidnapping or some
way to get them out of the country. And then

1567.text:
they're in Jordan or in Lebanon or in Turkey,
if they manage to get there, without any familial

1573.text:
support. And they also don't -- and these
host countries see them as a danger. Young

1579.text:
men tend to be seen as dangerous, open to
radicalization and such.

1584.text:
And yet if they get caught and sent back to
Syria, they will certainly be at the very

1589.text:
least imprisoned and most likely tortured,
and many of them executed or tortured to death,

1596.text:
or those sorts of things, for deserting the
army. And I would encourage us to think about

1600.text:
this particular population that is -- you
know, that is in a situation of forced conscription

1604.text:
to fight in this god-awful situation, to think
of them as vulnerable, I mean, along with

1611.text:
other people, because those are the very people
that have -- are doing the fighting, and if

1617.text:
we can remove them from the fighting, then
we can play a role as a humanitarian aid community,

1623.text:
et cetera, in sort of trying to stop the fighting.
PARASILITI: Well, thank you. Great discussion.

1630.text:
We now invite our audience members to join
in. Please wait for a microphone and speak

1635.text:
directly into it and state your name and affiliation
and keep your comments and questions concise

1641.text:
so we can get in as many as possible.
Barbara Slavin?

1646.text:
QUESTION: Thanks, Andrew. Barbara Slavin from
the Atlantic Council and Al-Monitor. I wanted

1655.text:
to ask -- I mean, I know it's very difficult
to get statistics, but if you have any idea

1660.text:
what percentage of the children, refugee children
are getting some form of education, what percentage

1668.text:
of the refugees who are adults have any form
of gainful employment at all.

1675.text:
And, Ms. Davis, also your comments about these
young men, any idea how many of these young

1681.text:
men are out there who've deserted military
service? Thanks.

1685.text:
DAVIS: You want me to try and answer that?
CRISP: No, I can't answer it, actually. I

1692.text:
mean, that's a kind of baseline data that
would be extremely useful to have. I suspect

1696.text:
that somewhere hidden away in UNHCR that information
is available. I could make an attempt to retrieve

1701.text:
it.
I think some forms of information are more

1704.text:
easy to find than others. For example, percentage
of children in education, it should be possible

1709.text:
to find a rough figure. I think in terms of
livelihoods for adults, much more difficult

1714.text:
to get that, because people are working part-time
or on-and-off or occasionally or in the informal

1719.text:
sector, so that might be more difficult. But
I think getting that kind of basic demographic

1723.text:
data would be an important part of running
a successful refugee relief operation.

1728.text:
DAVIS: I can answer parts of that. Six months
or so ago, there were about -- roughly 30

1737.text:
percent of Syrian children, maybe less, maybe
25 percent, were enrolled in school. The highest

1742.text:
number was in Jordan, which was...
QUESTION: You mean the refugee children?

1746.text:
DAVIS: Refugee children, sorry, yes. Syrian
refugee children were enrolled in school.

1748.text:
Highest number was in Jordan, which was around
40 percent, I think. I would also have to

1754.text:
check statistics. There are a number of issues.
There's also informal education, which is

1762.text:
a little bit different, and whether people
count that as school or not, enrolled in school,

1766.text:
I don't know.
Turkey's -- the refugees in Turkey are not

1770.text:
under the statistical -- they're not under
UNHCR. They're under the Turkish AFAD body.

1779.text:
And so these statistics are not necessarily
available for Turkey, although the Turkish

1783.text:
government is producing them, but they don't
-- they may not be kept in the same way that

1787.text:
the UNHCR keeps them. So everything is this
multiple system of putting numbers together.

1792.text:
About employment, it's in no one's interest
to publish those numbers on unemployment,

1798.text:
because if people -- if the governments start
to see that there are 50 percent of Syrians

1803.text:
in Jordan are gainfully employed, they will
potentially start cracking down on them. And

1807.text:
so I think that -- I think everybody just
doesn't talk about it.

1812.text:
And the young men, you asked about the numbers.
When we look at the breakdown of the statistics

1819.text:
in terms of who is registered as a refugee,
in Egypt and in Iraq, and now in Turkey, there

1826.text:
are more male refugees registered than female
refugees, whereas in Lebanon and Jordan, there

1831.text:
are more females than male. So the number
is still about 50 percent, 49.8 percent versus

1836.text:
50.2 percent or something. I mean, it's -- it
sort of -- it's right on the 50 percent.

1843.text:
To me, that's statistically significant because
when we think about -- if there's 200,000

1850.text:
people who've been killed in Syria, the vast
majority of them are men. So already you have

1856.text:
a lesser Syrian male population. But also,
it's traditionally women and children who

1862.text:
sort of flee as refugees. But similarly, we
have flights where 50 percent of them are

1867.text:
men or otherwise. That to me says that they're
fleeing in much larger numbers for a variety

1872.text:
of reasons.
CRISP: If I could just maybe add -- link to

1873.text:
the issues you brought up, which is education
and employment. I think one of the most disturbing

1878.text:
characteristics of the Syrian refugee situation
at the moment is the number of children who

1882.text:
are being taken out of school in order to
work to meet the household budgetary needs.

1887.text:
And one of the questions -- which is a little
bit of a mystery, and it needs -- some more

1891.text:
work needs to be done on it -- is exactly
how are the Syrian refugees making ends meet?

1895.text:
We know that they brought some -- normally
they brought some resources with them, but

1899.text:
normally those have now been depleted. The
cost of living is often going up in the places

1903.text:
that they've fled to because of the sheer
numbers of people. Assistance programs -- for

1907.text:
example, my colleagues were in Lebanon recently
and reported quite a substantial cutback in

1912.text:
the assistance provided to Syrian refugees.
We know that there is some money coming in

1916.text:
through remittances and some money coming
in through working in the informal sector,

1920.text:
but exactly how people manage to make ends
meet, other than going through kind of what

1925.text:
I would call negative coping mechanisms, which
is, you know, sending your kids out to work

1929.text:
when they should be in school, I think that's
something where we need some more understanding.

1933.text:
PARASILITI: There's a question over here.
QUESTION: Tom Petri, House of Representatives.

1941.text:
You touched on this, but, I mean, I just don't
know the answer. Maybe you could help. You're

1946.text:
focusing on the refugees, but not particularly
on the -- how the international committee

1952.text:
is coordinating or not or maximizing its good
effect, rather than creating more problems

1959.text:
through not dealing with young men or doing
it poorly or whatever.

1964.text:
Could you assess -- or how we coordinate or
who's in charge of all this and how we can

1969.text:
make sure we're actually being effective,
more effective?

1973.text:
CRISP: Maybe I have a first go at that one.
As I said earlier, I think one of the interesting

1978.text:
and important characteristics of this refugee
situation is the number of people living outside

1983.text:
of camps, within the community, alongside
nationals. And as I mentioned earlier, that

1987.text:
has some, you know, potential advantages and
some potential disadvantages.

1992.text:
I think one of the issues that it's thrown
up quite starkly is that you have a country

1997.text:
like Lebanon where one in four of the population
is now a refugee, so this is obviously having

2002.text:
a very important impact on the Lebanese citizens
that have absorbed these people into their

2008.text:
cities and their towns and their villages.
From an institutional point of view, it's

2012.text:
not actually clear who's responsible for assisting
host communities. UNHCR as a refugee agency

2019.text:
will say, well, that's not really our business.
Maybe we can provide a little bit of assistance

2023.text:
on the side to make sure that host communities
are not too disadvantaged by having refugees

2029.text:
in their presence.
But at the end of the day, UNHCR would say,

2032.text:
Our mandate is to protect and find solutions
for refugees, not for local people. So there

2037.text:
seems to be a potential gap, or an actual
gap, in the UN system when it comes to focusing

2043.text:
on the host communities.
Now I guess one obvious answer to that kind

2048.text:
of conundrum is to say, Well, it's really
development agencies that have a more important

2052.text:
responsibility than the humanitarian agencies.
I would probably have to say that in the Syrian

2059.text:
context, as in many other humanitarian contexts,
getting a smooth transition from the kind

2064.text:
of short-term, immediate refugee relief, humanitarian
assistance to the longer-term infrastructural

2070.text:
and economic support provided by development
organizations, seems to be taking place rather

2075.text:
slowly -- rather more slowly than people wanted
or, indeed, anticipated.

2079.text:
But I think this whole question of who supports
the host communities is a really central issue

2084.text:
to arise out of this citizens and one that
is now receiving much more attention from

2088.text:
the humanitarian community than at any other
previous point that I can remember.

2092.text:
DAVIS: Can I add something on that? The -- one
of the things that I think is unique about

2096.text:
also the Syrian refugee situation is that
UNHCR has stepped into the fray and tried

2103.text:
to organize everybody. There's a huge portal
you can go to that tells you who's doing the

2108.text:
water projects and what part of what governorate
in Jordan or in Lebanon or wherever, so you

2112.text:
can -- and it's all available to the public,
so you can actually access all of that and

2116.text:
see it.
And it coordinates -- the money that comes

2119.text:
in and what the projects are going to be.
And I don't -- I think that that is fairly

2122.text:
unique in our -- in our history. So that is
being done much better than it has ever done

2129.text:
-- been done before.
When I talked about sort of the strong centralized

2133.text:
states with the deep state kind of -- versus
the weaker ones, Jordan, for example, has

2139.text:
to -- the Ministry of Planning and something
-- the Ministry of Planning has to approve

2145.text:
every project that is established for refugees.
And up until the recent present, they would

2152.text:
not let vocational training be done for Syrian
refugees, whereas they used to allow that

2156.text:
all the time for Iraqis, with the idea that
they are -- that the Syrians start getting

2161.text:
vocational training, they're going to start
working in jobs in Jordan and they don't want

2164.text:
them to.
So Jordan keeps sort of a tight hand on what

2167.text:
any -- what any licensed NGO does. Now, there
are charitable organizations in Jordan that

2174.text:
do whatever they want because they're charities
and they have different relationships and

2178.text:
different funding streams, the ones that Jeff
mentioned, coming from the Gulf, for example.

2182.text:
In Lebanon, though, the government has such
little sort of -- the central government has

2190.text:
such little say in what's going in the country
and little, I mean, control over it, as well,

2195.text:
that there is sort of everything in Lebanon.
And the UNHCR have sort of put money out to

2202.text:
where -- the people that it knows -- you know,
I mean, when I was in Lebanon, I ran across

2206.text:
missionaries out there teaching Christianity
to these Syrians in these camps. And that

2211.text:
was not being well-received by the parents,
for example. One guy said to me, "These kids

2218.text:
are so small, they don't even know Muhammed.
Why should they know Jesus?", is what he said.

2223.text:
CRISP: Something we saw in Jordan, which I
thought was quite progressive, is a situation

2228.text:
in which you have, you know, Syrian refugees
living alongside very poor members of the

2232.text:
Jordanian community, and in some cases, no
better off at all than the refugees, and the

2236.text:
government has stipulated to humanitarian
agencies, yes, it's fine for you to work with

2240.text:
the refugees, but we want 25 percent of your
budget devoted to poorer members of the local

2245.text:
population.
I thought that set an interesting precedent.

2247.text:
I thought it was quite a progressive move.
And it is a step in the right direction in

2252.text:
terms of meeting the needs of the host communities.
And I wouldn't be at all surprised if other

2255.text:
refugee-hosting states start adopting similar
mechanisms.

2259.text:
PARASILITI: Question right there.
QUESTION: Thank you. Michael Barnett, George

2263.text:
Washington University. And I think this is
mainly for Jeff. One of the characteristics

2268.text:
of humanitarian emergencies is that the humanitarian
community afterwards almost always says, "We

2274.text:
did more harm than good." And ever since Mary
Anderson's pledge of Do No Harm, the humanitarian

2280.text:
community has constantly evoked this concern
that they're doing more harm than good and

2286.text:
have admonished themselves so that in the
future they need to make sure that they minimize

2291.text:
the harm and maximize the good.
To what extent is that conversation taking

2296.text:
place in the humanitarian community today
vis-a-vis Syria? And can you tell us in general

2304.text:
whether you think there's any question about
whether the humanitarian community is doing

2309.text:
more harm than good?
CRISP: I would have to be totally honest on

2313.text:
that question and say that, in my interaction
with people involved in the Syrian refugee

2317.text:
operation, I've not heard a lot of concern
about that question as to whether the humanitarian

2323.text:
system or community is doing more harm than
good. My impression is that people are really

2327.text:
racing to meet the immediate needs of the
influx, which has been faster than any of

2332.text:
recent years, and so there's more kind of
long term, and maybe actually even more philosophical

2338.text:
questions have gone by the wayside.
I'm sure, as you said, you know, in retrospect

2343.text:
when we come to the look at the Syrian operation
in five or ten years' time, we'll find plenty

2347.text:
of ways in which things could have done -- been
done better, been done differently and done

2352.text:
in a way which caused more good and less harm.
But I don't think, as far as I'm aware, at

2358.text:
least, that process of introspection is yet
taking place.

2362.text:
DAVIS: Can I just add one thing onto that?
And I completely agree with what Jeff is saying.

2367.text:
I think -- particularly talking outside of
Syria, I think when we look inside Syria,

2371.text:
I think we have a lot more soul-searching
that will need to be done, because I think

2376.text:
we've really failed on that account.
Primarily, I think there are two things. The

2383.text:
first one is, the U.N. did not send aid into
the non-regime-controlled areas of Syria until

2390.text:
-- I think it was July or August of this year.
They made the decision that they were only

2395.text:
going to work with Damascus and with the regime.
And so all aid going into Syria went through

2400.text:
the regime, which meant incredible levels
of hunger and depravation and sickness and

2406.text:
all of that that goes with that in the non-regime-controlled
areas, and aid then became a weapon in the

2412.text:
war. The regime used it against those in the
non-regime-controlled areas.

2418.text:
That to me was -- I think that the U.N. should
look back on that and say that was not the

2424.text:
right decision. We should have much sooner
-- they also would have stemmed the refugee

2428.text:
flows much sooner had they gotten more aid
inside Syria and said to the regime, "We don't

2434.text:
care." But, you know, this is in retrospect,
looking back a bit, of course I can say this.

2438.text:
And I -- you know, the decisions were made
at a particular time.

2441.text:
But the second thing that I think we always
need to keep front-and-center and remember

2445.text:
is that the best scenario for these refugees
and for taking care of refugees and for making

2449.text:
their lives better is to end the fighting
in Syria so that they can go back. And without

2454.text:
that, we're just, you know, putting Band-Aids
on things.

2458.text:
PARASILITI: Yes, right -- third row, please.
QUESTION: Thank you. Nancy Wilson from Relief

2467.text:
International. We've got an enormous amount
of work going on in and around Syria. And

2471.text:
I think some of the points you made about
the weak government and also the local population

2477.text:
bear further exploration. Certainly, one is
the competition for wages, driving wages down,

2483.text:
and housing -- driving housing prices up.
But one of the pieces that struck me as unusual

2492.text:
were the number of Lebanese near the Syrian
border who previously went into Syria to get

2497.text:
health care. And now with that border closed
and things falling apart, they're in worse

2501.text:
shape even in their own country.
And so the availability of funding, which

2508.text:
we found UNICEF to be quite generous in looking
at upwards of 30 percent of support that we

2513.text:
provide for -- can go for Lebanese families
to be quite an important piece, because that's

2520.text:
just really unrecognizable as a problem historically.
The other is the increasing pressure to actually

2528.text:
invest in strengthening Lebanese government
institutions. So in a way, seeing the government

2533.text:
start to try and leverage this flow of resources
to solve problems that it's had for a very

2537.text:
long time, and I think that's going to be
a confounding matter for the relief and development

2543.text:
organizations, trying to figure out how to
weigh those things up in the balance, so where

2549.text:
governments start to use the presence of refugee
assistance in order to meet other needs that

2554.text:
they're finding.
But I think the tension is rising between

2557.text:
the Lebanese and Syrians and could flash in
some very unpleasant ways quite soon.

2565.text:
PARASILITI: Comments? Please.
QUESTION: I'm Audrey Kurth Cronin from George

2574.text:
Mason University. If you were strictly looking
from the perspective of the refugee crisis,

2580.text:
how would you critique recent U.S. and European
policy in a broader sense toward the conflicts

2586.text:
in Iraq and Syria, and especially toward ISIS?
PARASILITI: Jeffrey?

2590.text:
CRISP: OK. Well, as a representative of a
humanitarian and non-political agency, I'm

2596.text:
going to duck the political and military implications
of that question. I would say that as a European

2603.text:
myself, the European response on the humanitarian
front has been disappointing in some respects.

2610.text:
There have been some exceptions, such as Sweden
and Germany have admitted quite a substantial

2614.text:
number of Syrian refugees, but Europe as a
whole seems quite content for the refugees

2619.text:
to remain within the Middle East region and
has not responded particularly positively

2624.text:
to the high commissioner's request for resettlement
places in Europe.

2627.text:
Now, of course, those states would argue,
yes, but we've been pumping large amounts

2631.text:
of money into the relief operation. And there
is certainly a considerable amount of truth

2636.text:
to that statement. At the same time, I think
it would have been a more positive engagement

2641.text:
of the European states in terms of asylum
and refugee resettlement would have actually

2646.text:
been rather welcome, but we'll leave the political
and military issues to my colleague.

2651.text:
DAVIS: As a tenured professor at Georgetown,
I can take on the political, I suppose. I

2658.text:
see there are sort of two factors that got
missed somewhere along the way. And one was

2667.text:
underestimating what the U.S. invasion of
Iraq did in 2003, in terms of allowing in

2679.text:
a type of fighter and a type of person that
-- allowing it to develop in Iraq, but also

2686.text:
allowing it to come from other places, that
has now manifest itself in the Islamic State

2692.text:
sort of actors.
And I just don't think we ever got that, or

2697.text:
we did and we didn't want to acknowledge it.
But when the Syrian government sometime in

2703.text:
2011 lost control of the border with Iraq,
to me that was like, "Oh, no." I mean, not

2710.text:
that it -- not that the Syrians or the Iraqis
ever had very strong control of that border,

2715.text:
but when it disappeared, that was just then
open door.

2718.text:
So, you know, it conflated them in a way.
And that nothing was done at that point to

2724.text:
me -- I think is more about the Americans'
unwillingness to recognize how -- just how

2733.text:
bad what they did in Iraq actually has become.
The second issue I think that's really important

2742.text:
is Russia. And nobody sort of talks about
Russia or Russia's role or -- and without

2749.text:
Russian support of the Assad regime, we would
not be having this conversation. I mean, the

2756.text:
Russian regime has basically been a pipeline
of everything that the regime needs to keep

2763.text:
it afloat, because they run -- they don't
manufacture their own bullets and their own,

2767.text:
you know, helicopter parts or any of those
sorts of things. So that's all been coming.

2770.text:
And that, the U.S. is kind of -- I mean, they
know it, but they don't want to address it

2775.text:
head-on for all sorts of other geopolitical
reasons.

2778.text:
And then there is Iran, which has also taken
a role in there. And then when Hezbollah joined

2783.text:
the fray in 2013, that -- at that point, I
said to Syrians that I knew, as well as others,

2791.text:
this is no longer about Syria. This is about
everybody else on the globe, and Syria is

2796.text:
now just the field in which all of these battles
are going to be played out.

2800.text:
That's my five minutes of that.
PARASILITI: Yes, in the back?

2808.text:
QUESTION: Hi, Matthew Hale from the Lifeline
Embattled Civil Society Fund. My question

2814.text:
-- I wanted to follow up a little bit about
civil society within the refugee population.

2820.text:
What has been effective to get information
out? Where have they been effective in being

2825.text:
watchdogs? And what other support do they
need? And how can they function better?

2832.text:
CRISP: You have any experience there?
DAVIS: No.

2837.text:
CRISP: (OFF-MIKE)
DAVIS: That's a really difficult question.

2842.text:
And I think it's different in different cases
and different situations and different places.

2852.text:
I think there are traditional leaders -- so
Syria, before 2011, had very little civil

2859.text:
society. It had a lot of -- it had a lot of
government control, and it had a lot of people

2865.text:
in government positions, so there were all
sorts of what we would call nongovernmental

2871.text:
organizations in Syria that were all governmental
organizations, but that were totally controlled

2875.text:
by the regime. And there were religious charities,
as well, particularly Christian religious

2880.text:
charities that had roles.
So there's not a long and deep tradition among

2885.text:
Syrians of having civil society active in
Syria, because of the repression of the regime.

2891.text:
So when people have come out as refugees,
there are people who had various roles who

2896.text:
were organizers or teachers or other things
who have stepped in and done those sorts of

2901.text:
things.
Within Syria, there's tons of civil society

2905.text:
organizing and resistance in various ways
that has been largely -- I would say -- squashed

2915.text:
and executed. I mean, I think the people have
been killed, not just -- not just that the

2920.text:
civil society -- they just actually eliminated
the humans that did the work. And that's not

2926.text:
just the regime that eliminated them. All
sorts of people eliminated them.

2929.text:
But -- so I think in the camps, those sorts
of connections are growing, but I think it's

2935.text:
also -- because as Jeff said, so many of them
are outside of camps, so many people are living

2940.text:
in the local communities, that it's -- that
sometimes it's in the local communities where

2945.text:
people are saying we'll give this building
to you to use as a school. So can you guys

2950.text:
find the teachers, for example?
And then the Syrian community will say, oh,

2954.text:
yeah, we know three teachers who live over
there and they bring them in, and then they

2957.text:
